wordpressPost.title: There’s no place for old people
wordpressPost.content:
There’s no place for old people

I’ve always said “there’s no place for old people.” Â I’m turning 50 next month and yeah, I know, I was young once. Â I have nothing against the younger generation as I see them as being one of the most creative generations there has ever been.

I didn’t say the most inventive (but close) however, definitely, the most creative. Â To live in a time of such creativity with the minds of young people that create systems and platforms from just pure imagination, is a gift that I feel honored to be a part of.

Let’s be honest here, my mother is 71 years old and she has no clue about technology, apps or, where the world has the potential to go.

The closest thing she sees outside of her world is the YouTube channel that I set up for her on her living room television.

She’s fascinated to see the world through the eyes of others, more specifically, through real life videos and what she has and will, never experience.

The truth is, at her age, YouTube will be the closest that she’ll ever get to a world outside of herself. Â And with that, I say, have fun mom.. Do what makes you happy while you still can.

Back to my initial topic of “there’s no place for old people.” Â Sorry my ADHD kicks in quite often!! Â Actually, about every five seconds and it’s only getting worse as I age.. But it’s also my gift as well as my curse.

Okay, now what was I talking about? Oh yeah!

They say the older you get the faster you get older. Â I know what this means because the last ten to twenty years have flown by. Â Each day flies by in fact, and I watch the clock and instead of when I was younger, wanting the time to go by as fast as possible, I watch the clock as my heart sinks and I fear that another day is about to end. I hate how fast time is going but, I have no control over time. We’re all going to get old whether we like it or not.

I’m getting older and if life goes faster now that I’m older then how much longer do I have, I wonder? Â Right now I still look reasonably okay and I am able to do anything physically. Â The real worry is when, I get to that age where I’m really old and when people look past me. Â Like being invisible. Which is not very far away even if I still feel and act like I’m eighteen!

Society loves youth and society rewards youth and, probably like most others, I feel like I didn’t appreciate my youth when I had it. Â With that said, I like most people, did the best I could with what I had, and for that, I am grateful for who I am today.

If I could sum up what I’m trying to say here is just read the lyrics the Baz Luhrmann, Wear Sunscreen song below.

“Enjoy the power and beauty of your youth
Oh, never mindÂ You will not understand the power and beauty of your youth until they have fadedÂ But trust me, in 20 years youâ€™ll look back at photos of yourself
And recall in a way you canâ€™t grasp nowÂ How much possibility lay before you
And how fabulous you really looked”

“Donâ€™t worry about the future
Or worryÂ But know that worrying is as effective as trying to solve an algebra equation by chewing bubblegumÂ The real troubles in your life are apt to be things that never crossed your worried mindÂ The kind that blindside you at 4 PM on some idle Tuesday
Do one thing everyday that scares you”

“Donâ€™t be reckless with other peopleâ€™s heartsÂ Donâ€™t put up with people who are reckless with yours”

“Donâ€™t waste your time on jealousyÂ Sometimes youâ€™re ahead, sometimes youâ€™re behind
The race is longÂ And in the end, itâ€™s only with yourself”

“Remember the compliments you receive, forget the insultsÂ If you succeed in doing this, tell me how”

I don’t know about you but, I think those are some pretty powerful lyrics and you pretty much have to be older to appreciate them.

I feel like I have some time to do the things that I want and to love the people who are in my life and, who I know Â will naturally leave me sooner than I hope.

Maybe that’s the key to getting old. Â We become fulfilled with the love that we give and the things we did while we are here. Â Once you can or have done this, you can begin to step back and let others have the space that you once had.

Maybe its not looking at others like they’re taking your space at all but, it’s just the natural form of energy that we as old people have to transfer so that energy can re-circulate so that, the younger generation can have it to use.

Whatever the rest of my days will bring me and no matter how fast they come, I will remember that, Â I got to live an incredible life because it was my life.

Even if didn’t create some huge powerful company, an app that changed the world or, I wasn’t the most beautiful woman in the world, I had the opportunity to grow old and for some they don’t even get that chance.

All that will matter in the space and time I have left is that I was born, born free, I created some beautiful kids and I was nice, giving, loving and compassionate towards others.

I guess the whole point to this blog post is not so much about “there’s no place for old people” but about “reflection is the greatest gift an old person can give themself.”
